description: This course provides an introduction to the quantitative methods used in characterizing and engineering biomolecular properties and cellular behavior, focusing primarily on receptor-mediated phenomena. The thermodynamics and kinetics of protein/ligand binding are covered, with an emphasis on experimental techniques for measuring molecular parameters such as equilibrium affinities, kinetic rate constants, and diffusion coefficients. Approaches for probing and altering these molecular properties of proteins are also described, including site-directed mutagenesis, directed evolution, rational design, and covalent modification. Equilibrium, kinetic, and transport models are used to elucidate the relationships between the aforementioned molecular parameters and cellular processes such as ligand/receptor binding and trafficking, cell adhesion and motility, signal transduction, and gene regulation.
name: BIOMOLEC & CELLULAR ENG

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to the quantitative methods used in characterizing and engineering biomolecular properties and cellular behavior, focusing primarily on receptor-mediated phenomena. The thermodynamics and kinetics of protein/ligand binding are covered, with an emphasis on experimental techniques for measuring molecular parameters such as equilibrium affinities, kinetic rate constants, and diffusion coefficients. Approaches for probing and altering these molecular properties of proteins are also described, including site-directed mutagenesis, directed evolution, rational design, and covalent modification. Equilibrium, kinetic, and transport models are used to elucidate the relationships between the aforementioned molecular parameters and cellular processes such as ligand/receptor binding and trafficking, cell adhesion and motility, signal transduction, and gene regulation.

Most of the students who took this class enjoyed it. They felt like they learned a lot from the lectures. Some students wished that “more classes could be of similar quality.” They felt comfortable with the layout of this graduate-level course and thought that the lecture material “seemed to build in an appropriate and useful way.” However, some students did express that they wished that course material would have included more in-depth analysis. 

Many students shared the opinion that Dr. Sarkar was able to present the course material in a “structured and comprehendible manner.” However, some did believe that he was not able to “stimulate [enough] conversation” during the lecture, and he did not work out enough examples in class. This led to a gap between the lecture material and homework expectations. But, overall, students were very pleased with Dr. Sarkar’s teaching ability. They generally agreed that Dr. Sarkar “genuinely cares” about students understanding the material. 

This course was very difficult for many of the undergraduates that took it. Students seemed to feel that the homework and exam material were much harder than the material that was covered in class.
